newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: RUGBY UNION-UNTRIED DU PLESSIS REPLACES MARKGRAAFF.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-UNTRIED DU PLESSIS REPLACES MARKGRAAFF.

text.p: The South African Rugby Football Union (SARFU) turned to the untried Carel du Plessis to replace disgraced Andre Markgraaff as Springbok coach on Tuesday.
Described in his playing days as the "prince of wings", Du Plessis, 36, becomes the youngest coach in the Springboks history.
He has the dual responsibility of leading his country through a gruelling 13 internationals in 1997 as well as healing some of the game's self-inflicted wounds.
"It is not only about obtaining results. It's also the showcase which SARFU has to present to the rugby public, the disadvantaged communities and internationally," said du Plessis.
"I believe that I can perform the job of coach at a high level because it's not always about experience. It's about vision, it's about equipping players for test rugby."

The former Western Province and Springbok winger -- unrelated to South Africa's World Cup winning manager Morne du Plessis -- retired at the age of 29 as sporting isolation limited his international career to just 12 tests between 1982 and 1989.
Since quitting rugby he has made a career as a gilts trader and is a partner in a Cape Town corporate services company.
He returned to the game in an official capacity only when Markgraaff employed him as tactical adviser during the Springboks' five-test clean sweep on their tour of Argentina, France and Wales.
"Carel is a great leader and visionary and he possesses a shrewd rugby mind," said SARFU chief executive Rian Oberholzer.
"The executive committee of SARFU are confident that he can knit together the different strands of Springbok rugby and come up with a winning combination."
Du Plessis captained Western Province during a golden era in the 1980s, playing alongside brothers Willie and Michael.
A new manager is expected to be announced next week along with a backroom team. The roles of manager and coach had been united under Markgraaff but have again been divided.
Markgraaff resigned last week after a secret tape recording was published of a conversation in which he made racist remarks against black sports officials.
